awd_abstract_narration:
There are significant advantages in the development of flexible laser materials based on organic and biological materials, which could have wide-ranging applications including those in wearable sensors. This project applies a fundamental approach to advantage of the inherit polarization properties of cellulose nanocrystals (CNC) to create new lasing materials. The challenges investigators address are the toxicity, water solubility and stability of organic materials. To address these barriers, they will explore the properties of a diverse classes of materials.

The PI provides good evidence that CNC films have left-handed circular dichroism that can be enhanced and modified by inclusion of polymers, which can further increase the strength and flexibility of the films. To produce lasing materials, the PIs plan to incorporate quantum dots (QDs) into the films.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
The ultimate goal of this project is to mimic nature in optical manipulation by developing a chiral nematic organization of cellulose nanocrystals based optoelectronic devices and template-assisted co-assembly of functional molecules for optical communication, biosensing, and color appearance. In this project, we focused to achieve the photonically-active multi-valued logic systems and integration with water-soluble and photo-stable quantum dots to construct free-standing and flexible nanocomposite films to realize solid-state advanced lasing materials with unusual optical functionality exhibiting dynamic circular polarized emission with on-demand handedness controlled by remote chemical and light stimuli.

To this end, we explored three main components for chiral optoelectronic device applications as organic thin film transistors. The manipulated wavelength of the transmitted light absorption and the other reflected light wavelengths produce an adjustable photonic bandgap that directly matches the resulting capacity output and source drain current for the capacitors and bioelectronic devices. Second, doped chiral nematic materials were used to control the transmission of light in visible spectra. These optically active biomaterials with chiral nematic-like tissues of cellulose nanocrystals inserted with organic dyes have been manipulated to produce strong circular polarizable photoluminescence for structural color control similar to beetles and insects.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its conten
